title: Jnana Yoga
description: A progressive exploration of Jnana Yoga, the path of knowledge and wisdom, its core philosophies, practices, and goal of liberation.

paragraphs.summary: An introduction to Jnana Yoga as one of the primary paths to spiritual liberation in Hindu philosophy, emphasizing the pursuit of wisdom through discriminative knowledge and self-inquiry.
The ultimate aim of Jnana Yoga: liberation (Moksha) from the cycle of birth and death (samsara) and realization of one's true Self (Atman) as identical with Brahman.
Spiritual ignorance; the fundamental misapprehension of reality, particularly mistaking the non-Self (ego, body-mind) for the true Self (Atman).
The cosmic power that veils the ultimate reality (Brahman) and projects the appearance of the manifold, illusory world of names and forms.
The ultimate, impersonal, and unconditioned Reality in Hinduism; the ground of all existence, often described as Sat-Chit-Ananda.
The true, innermost Self of the individual, which is eternal, unchanging, and ultimately identical with Brahman.
The core realization of Advaita Vedanta: the individual Self (Atman) is non-different from the ultimate Reality (Brahman).
A method of inquiry ('not this, not that') used to negate all that is not the Self (Atman/Brahman), leading to the realization of what remains.
The crucial faculty of discriminating between the eternal (Real, Atman) and the ephemeral (unreal, anƒÅtman, world-appearances).
Non-attachment or indifference to sensual pleasures and worldly objects, arising from the understanding of their impermanent nature.
Ancient Sanskrit texts containing central philosophical concepts of Hinduism, forming the foundation of Vedanta and Jnana Yoga.
A Sanskrit text, attributed to Badarayana, that systematizes and summarizes the philosophical and spiritual ideas in the Upanishads.
The aspects of the Bhagavad Gita that emphasize the path of knowledge, self-realization, and understanding the nature of reality.
A major school of Vedanta philosophy, most famously expounded by Adi Shankaracharya, asserting the non-dual nature of Brahman and Atman.
An influential text by Gaudapada, often considered a foundational work for Advaita Vedanta, commenting on the Mandukya Upanishad.
Adi Shankaracharya's extensive commentaries (Bhashyas) on the Upanishads, Brahma Sutras, and Bhagavad Gita, which are seminal texts for Advaita Vedanta.
A song of the sage Ribhu, part of the Shivarahasya Purana, expounding non-dual (Advaitic) truth and the path to Self-realization.
A classical Advaita Vedanta scripture written as a dialogue between the sage Ashtavakra and King Janaka, known for its direct and uncompromising non-dual teachings.
A text of Advaita Vedanta attributed to Dattatreya, expressing the state and wisdom of an Avadhuta (a liberated, unconventional sage).
The three ordinary states of consciousness (Jagrat - waking, Svapna - dreaming, Sushupti - deep dreamless sleep) analyzed in Vedanta to point to the underlying Witness.
The 'fourth' state of consciousness, beyond the three ordinary states; pure awareness, the Witness, the nature of Atman.
The practice of investigating the nature of the 'I'-thought or ego-sense, typically by persistently asking 'Who am I?', to trace it back to its source in the Self (Atman).
Understanding the mind as a flow of thoughts, an instrument of perception and cognition, but not the true Self; its tendencies and how to transcend them.
The principle of 'I-making' or ego-sense; the identification of the Self with the limited body-mind complex, which is the root of bondage.
The higher mental faculty of discrimination, reason, judgment, and decision-making; when purified, it aids in discerning the Real.
The pure, detached awareness that observes all mental and physical phenomena without involvement or identification; a key aspect of Atman.
The state of perceived limitation, suffering, and entrapment in the cycle of samsara, arising from ignorance (avidya) of one's true nature.
The relationship between action (Karma) and knowledge (Jnana); often, selfless action purifies the mind, making it fit for the path of knowledge.
The 'fourfold qualification' or means prescribed in Vedanta for a spiritual aspirant: Viveka, Vairagya, Shatsampat, and Mumukshutva.
The 'six treasures' or virtues: Shama (mental quietude), Dama (sense control), Uparati (cessation/withdrawal), Titiksha (forbearance), Shraddha (faith), Samadhana (concentration).
Calmness or tranquility of the mind, achieved by detaching from desires and mental agitations.
Control or restraint of the outer sense organs, preventing them from pursuing external objects.
Cessation from worldly activities or distractions; self-withdrawal and independence from external dependencies.
The capacity to endure all afflictions and dualities (pleasure/pain, heat/cold) without agitation or complaint.
Faith or trust in the teachings of the scriptures and the words of the Guru, essential for steady progress.
Deep concentration or single-pointedness of the mind, keeping it steadily focused on the goal.
An intense, burning desire or yearning for Moksha (liberation) from the cycle of samsara.
The practice of systematically hearing or studying the sacred texts (especially Upanishads) under the guidance of a qualified Guru.
Deep intellectual reflection and contemplation upon the truths heard or read, to remove doubts and gain conviction.
Deep and sustained meditation on the non-dual Reality (Brahman/Atman) to directly realize the truth established through shravana and manana.
One of the Mahavakyas ('Great Sayings') from the Upanishads, meaning 'I am Brahman,' used for affirmation and realization of non-duality.
Another Mahavakya, meaning 'That Thou Art,' asserting the identity of the individual self (tvam/Atman) with the ultimate Reality (tat/Brahman).
The 'Great Sayings' of the Upanishads that encapsulate the highest Vedantic truths, often used as objects of contemplation.
A state of profound meditative absorption or trance where the mind becomes completely still and identified with the object of meditation or pure consciousness.
The highest state of Samadhi, characterized by complete cessation of thought and absorption in formless, undifferentiated Reality.
The state of natural, effortless, and continuous Self-realization, maintained even amidst worldly activities; the state of a Jivanmukta.
One who has attained liberation (Moksha) and Self-realization while still living in a physical body.
Liberation achieved at or after the death of the physical body, where the individual self merges completely with Brahman without future rebirth.
A subtle form of egoism characterized by pride, superiority, or attachment related to one's spiritual progress or experiences.
An early Indian philosopher and theologian who consolidated the doctrine of Advaita Vedanta and is credited with unifying and establishing the main currents of thought in Hinduism.
A renowned Indian sage of the 20th century who taught the path of Self-Inquiry ('Who am I?') as the most direct means to Self-realization.
An Indian spiritual teacher and philosopher of Advaita (Nondualism), known for his direct and impactful teachings, compiled in the book 'I Am That'.
Exploring the relationship and potential integration of the path of knowledge (Jnana) with the path of devotion (Bhakti).
Understanding how the path of knowledge (Jnana) relates to and can be supported by the path of selfless action (Karma Yoga).
Modern interpretations and adaptations of Vedanta philosophy, often seeking to reconcile traditional teachings with contemporary thought and science.
